body: When Citibank last month raised by 200 percent the minimum balance it requires for free checking, it sparked criticism from New York City officials and state legislators. State Senator Nellie Santiago, a Democrat of Brooklyn, denounced the bank as interested only in doing business with the wealthy. The city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Jose
title: Survey Finds Wide Range of Fees for Checking Accounts

body: Karen Hubert Allison, who with her husband, Len Allison, lived out every cook's fantasy of turning a home into a restaurant and later earned three stars for the establishment, Huberts, in Manhattan, died on Tuesday in Maui, Hawaii. She was 49 and had lived in Maui since 1995. The cause of death was breast cancer, said Dr. Wayne Lavender, a family
title: Karen Allison, 49, Restaurateur With Vision

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ABIGAIL ADAMS SMITH MUSEUM, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. Built in 1799 as the carriage house for the planned estate of Abigail Adams and Col. William Smith, the structure also served as the Mount Vernon Hotel from 1826 to 1833. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.; closed Mondays and holidays.

title: New York City Primary Choices

body: WHEN he first arrived in New York from Sierra Leone in 1982, Abdul Kargbo fell in love with Chinese food. He indulged often in chicken with broccoli, his favorite. But something bothered Mr. Kargbo, a Muslim: the food was cooked in the same wok as the pork dishes and with the same utensils. And the meat was not halal, meaning that the animals were
title: Where's the Pork? Not Here.

body: BRAWTA CARIBBEAN CAFE ++ (718) 855-5515; 347 Atlantic Avenue (Hoyt Street), Boerum Hill; $; all major credit cards. Relaxed and cheerful in atmosphere, this colorful little cafe delivers an enticing roster of spirited West Indian preparations. Among the highlights are the chicken roti, or large flatbread made with crushed chickpeas and rolled
title: Brooklyn's New Or Tried and True

body: When it comes to identifying ways to revitalize Sunset Park and Red Hook, the five Democrats who would like to represent Brooklyn's 38th Council District have a lot in common. All five have promised to lobby for another high school in the district. Each one backs plans to replace the perpetually gridlocked Gowanus Expressway with a tunnel closer to
title: Brooklyn Primary Is a Battle of Resumes and Endorsements

body: Primaries are the real elections in many heavily Democratic parts of Brooklyn, and next Tuesday's ballots will feature an unusual number of competitive races for New York City Council seats. These are our endorsements. 35th District (Fort Greene, Clinton Hill, Prospect Heights, part of Crown Heights): Mary Pinkett was the first African-American
title: Brooklyn Council Endorsements

body: IF there was one thing that New York City's community school boards could count on over the last quarter century -- if there was one constant that defined the realpolitik of education on the neighborhood level -- it was this: the school boards got to pick the principals. So it was no surprise when a school board member went to meet with the new
title: District Superintendents Are Supposed to Change the Public Schools. Can They?

body: On Aug. 23, Nicholas Heyward wore his pain on his body as well as his lips. His son's picture was inside a pendant that hung from a chain around his neck. His T-shirt advertised the Nicholas Heyward Jr. All-Star Memorial Classic basketball tournament. And Mr. Heyward told the small crowd assembled on the Gowanus Playground to commemorate what would
title: Another Birthday Marked for Dead Boy as Grief Holds On

body: WHEN they bought their Boerum Hill house in 1987, it needed just about everything: plumbing, electrical wiring, all new moldings. And like all first-time old-house buyers, they vowed to do most of the work themselves. ''I stripped the whole staircase,'' said Lulee Williams. ''Seven surgeries later -- yes, as a result I had repetitive stress injury;
title: Veterans of a Fixer-Upper Are Taking On Another

body: To the Editor: Perhaps the Duane Park Cafe came out of a movie shoot unscathed (''From Cafe to Wreck and Back Again,'' July 20) but here in Boerum Hill the community did not fare quite as well. Three summers ago, All That and a Bag of Chips, a movie production company, notified residents that the area had been selected as a location for a feature
title: Shooting of Movie Scarred Boerum Hill

body: In 1972, when Nancy Cogen opened the Melting Pot, a tie-dye clothing store on Atlantic Avenue, great expectations were in the air. A group of young entrepreneurs was renovating storefronts, with the idea of creating a pleasant shopping district. ''The hope was that there would be stores, and people would stroll the avenue,'' Ms. Cogen said. ''We
title: On Atlantic Avenue, Another Boom, at Least in Optimism

body: James Vacirca is the expert on Boerum Hill. With a glance at his colored maps and spreadsheets, he can tell how many commercial buildings there are, or vacant lots, or wheelchair-friendly curb cuts. Mr. Vacirca, a 62-year-old retired I.B.M. systems analyst, may be a man of facts, but he is also a dreamer. You can see it in his eyes when he talks
title: Like 'Jigsaw Puzzle,' Volunteers Build Neighborhood Profile

body: Produce Fresh From the Farms Community Supported Agriculture, a grass-roots cooperative of consumers and farmers that delivers produce from farms, is beginning its second season in New York City, and memberships are going fast. The program enables consumers at the start of the growing season to buy shares, which help support the farmers; in
title: Food Notes

body: THE neighborhood bike nuts are out in force. They fly down the street past fat minivans, bounce onto doorsteps, whip off their sleek helmets with a whoosh of triumph and shout a super-oxygenated, ''Hi!'' That big sound speaks tomes. Bicycles, they say, are the solution. And to what? You know. To what ails the world. ''I don't own a vehicle,'' said
title: The Cyclist's Fix For the Cities: Just Shift Gears

body: Marsha Meyers placed two bulging folders on the dining room table of her Boerum Hill apartment. Inside were fliers, letters from politicians, legal documents and photographs that outline her neighborhood's six-year fight to close a homeless center. ''We have 55 other social-service operators within a 46-block radius and we live with them,'' said
title: For a Shelter, Talk of Move But Just Talk

body: In a case closely watched by many lesbians in Brooklyn, a man accused of killing a Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, woman and raping the woman's companion during a 1995 robbery made a surprise turnabout in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday and pleaded guilty to the crimes days before his trial was to start. The plea by Alex Villaneuva, 20, before Judge Anne G.
title: A Surprise Guilty Plea In '95 Rape and Slaying

author: Peter Kaminsky writes the Underground Gourmet column for New York magazine.

title: Joys of Cooking

body: 'The Kids Bridge' Yeshiva University Museum 2520 Amsterdam Avenue, at West 185th Street Washington Heights (212) 960-5390 Recommended ages: 5 and up Through July 31 Robert Frost once said that good fences make good neighbors. The exhibition now on view at the Yeshiva University Museum offers a more friendly alternative: good bridges. ''The Kids

body: To the Editor: Aggressive dogs are usually the result of improper training and are not created by dog runs. On the contrary, dog runs are an invaluable aid in the socialization of dogs (and their owners). We encourage the Parks Department to develop additional runs as well as sponsor training classe so people can be educated in the proper handling
title: Owners, Not Dogs, Are Problem at Dog Runs

body: From the Ex-Lax Files Q. There's a building on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn that has ''Ex-Lax'' above the door. Am I right to assume it was an Ex-Lax factory? What is it now? A. A factory it was. But the Ex-Lax building on Atlantic Avenue, between Bond and Nevins Streets in Boerum Hill, was converted to loft co-ops in 1979. Marsha Meyers, board
title: F.Y.I.

body: IT'S another Saturday morning and Dan MacGowan, coffee cup at hand, is once again hunched at his desk, poring over the real estate listings. Kathy MacGowan, no longer an ardent adherent to this ritual, sits nearby, reading something -- anything! -- that does not have to do with apartment hunting. So it has been for too many weekends in the
title: In Much of the City, A Robust Market

body: Two weeks ago, 330 Brooklyn Democrats named Joan L. Millman, a retired teacher, to be their candidate in a special election to complete the term of the late Assemblywoman Eileen C. Dugan. title: The Nominee Chosen, the Charges Still Fly

body: As housing prices in Manhattan continue to climb, the Brooklyn town house market has started to soar, not only in Brooklyn Heights but also in nearby Cobble Hill, where houses are starting to sell for more than $1 million, a record for the neighborhood. At the same time, the number of houses being sold has also shot up, with one broker saying his
title: In Brooklyn Neighborhoods, Market for Town Houses Soars

body: WHAT New York City needs like the proverbial hole in the head -- one more chance for Jews and blacks to find themselves at each other's throat -- got its start yesterday at the Federal courthouse in Brooklyn. Two black men went on trial, charged with violating the civil rights of a young Hasid who was stabbed to death in the first of several nights
title: Another Trial To Tear Again At a Wound
